title: How to Sew a Button on Pants

steps.title: Remove the old button and thread.
steps.content: Remove the old button and thread. In order to attach a new button or replace the thread on a pair of pants, you must clear the way. If any of the old material is still attached, take it off, with scissors if necessary, in order to begin. [1] X Research source If you will be reusing the button, be sure to keep it on hand.

steps.title: Find a thread that matches the color of the pants.
steps.content: Find a thread that matches the color of the pants. Since you can see the thread above the button, you should pick thread that matches the fabric of your pants, or else the stitching will stick out. [2] X Research source Going with simple solid color that is close to the fabric is sufficient. It does not have to be a perfect match.

steps.title: Thread the needle with 1 foot (0.30 m) to 2 feet (0.61 m) of thread.
steps.content: Thread the needle with 1 foot (0.30 m) to 2 feet (0.61 m) of thread. Threading a needle can be a challenge on its own, but once you succeed, focus on getting an even amount of thread sticking out each end of the needle's eye by holding it out in front of you and eyeballing the distance. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Tie a knot at the end of the thread.
steps.content: Tie a knot at the end of the thread. An important step for an easy sewing experience is to tie off the thread before attempting to stitch. You can simply make a loop and roll the ends of the thread around between your fingers to make a tiny knot that will keep the thread from coming loose. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Mark the fabric on hard-to-find holes.
steps.content: Mark the fabric on hard-to-find holes. If the pants have difficult-to-see stitch holes, use bright lighting to track them down and mark them with a fabric pencil or other sturdy writing tool. This will make aligning the button on the pants much easier. [5] X Research source The marks belong on both sides of the fabric, where the button will sit. You can also stitch an 'X' in the spot where the button will be if you feel confident about your sewing abilities.

steps.title: Choose a 2-hole button to match other buttons.
steps.content: Choose a 2-hole button to match other buttons. A 2-hole button will not be the sturdiest, and for a pair of pants, which centers a great deal of pressure on the pants, a 4-hole button is preferable, particularly if there is only one. However, if the rest of the buttons are 2-hole buttons, it will do the job!

steps.title: Pierce the fabric below the button holes and pull through.
steps.content: Pierce the fabric below the button holes and pull through. To begin stitching the button, you just pierce through the underside and pull the needle upward through the button hole. [6] X Research source Pant fabric is often thick and sturdy. Be careful not to puncture your skin, as you may have to use a great deal of force to break through the fabric. You can use a thimble on your thumb to keep the needle from hurting you.

steps.title: Insert the needle downward into the opposite buttonhole.
steps.content: Insert the needle downward into the opposite buttonhole. A stitch is continued by piercing into the fabric from above through the buttonhole that the needle did not come up through. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Repeat the stitching process 4 to 5 times.
steps.content: Repeat the stitching process 4 to 5 times. Continue to thread the needle upward through one button hole and downward through the other hole. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the needle upward below the button.
steps.content: Pull the needle upward below the button. In order to strengthen the button in place, you must create a “shank” out of the thread by missing the button holes on your last repetition of the up-down cycle you did 4 to 5 times. Try to avoid moving to the side of the button, as this will reveal the shank. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Wrap the thread around the button.
steps.content: Wrap the thread around the button. To reinforce the stitch, you should make at least as many loops around the button as you stitched through the fabric. Keep the loops tight so that you are successfully reinforcing the button. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the needle downward below to the button.
steps.content: Pull the needle downward below to the button. Once again missing the button holes, pull the needle through the fabric below the button on the opposite side as where the needle came through. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Tie off the button on the underside by making a loop.
steps.content: Tie off the button on the underside by making a loop. Use the excess thread to make a loop below the button and pull the needle through, tying a simple knot with the thread. [12] X Research source You can repeat this process as many times as needed to make the button feel secure. Trim the thread directly above the knot to avoid undoing the knot by accident.

steps.title: Choose a 4-hole button to match others, or for a sturdier hold.
steps.content: Choose a 4-hole button to match others, or for a sturdier hold. While 2-hole buttons are much easier to stitch, 4-hole buttons are a stronger choice, as you can stitch them with an 'X' pattern to keep them firmly attached to your pants. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Use an 'X' pattern when stitching.
steps.content: Use an 'X' pattern when stitching. As usual, enter the button hole by piercing the fabric behind and catching the needle on the other side. Then, insert the needle downward through the buttonhole diagonal to the one you came up through. [14] X Research source Stitch in the same direction 4 to 5 times before switching to the other diagonal pair of holes. If there are other buttons that use a stitch that looks like two letter 'I's next to one another, called “II” stitches, you can stitch them to match by not crossing over to the diagonal hole when making the stitch. Instead, stitch through the hole straight across.

steps.title: Place a spacer below the button to leave enough room.
steps.content: Place a spacer below the button to leave enough room. An 'X' stitch in a 4-hole button is sturdy enough that it can be difficult to fit it through the buttonhole if it is sewn on too tightly. You can avoid this by using a piece of paper thin cardboard with a 1 inch (2.5 cm) wide 'V' cut into it and placing it below the button as you are stitching. [15] X Research source The spacer should not block the button holes, but keep the button's edge sitting above the fabric.

steps.title: Create a thread shank.
steps.content: Create a thread shank. A thread shank will strengthen the button, and can be completed by following the shanking instructions above. You simply miss the button on your last upward stitch and wrap it around the button before piercing back down to the underside of the pants. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Be sure to tie a knot below the button.
steps.content: Be sure to tie a knot below the button. The security of the 4-hole button can make it feel as though the button does not need extra support, but a knot is necessary to keep the button from un-threading itself and falling off the pants. Cut the fabric in the same way as with a 2-hole button.
